speaker: JULIET
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: SCENE I. Friar Laurence's cell.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Enter FRIAR LAURENCE and PARIS

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: On Thursday, sir? the time is very short.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: My father Capulet will have it so;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: You say you do not know the lady's mind:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Uneven is the course, I like it not.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalt's death,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And therefore have I little talk'd of love;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Now, sir, her father counts it dangerous

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: That she doth give her sorrow so much sway,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: And in his wisdom hastes our marriage,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: To stop the inundation of her tears;

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Which, too much minded by herself alone,

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: May be put from her by society:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Now do you know the reason of this haste.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: [Aside]  I would I knew not why it should be slow'd.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Look, sir, here comes the lady towards my cell.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Enter JULIET

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Happily met, my lady and my wife!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That may be, sir, when I may be a wife.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: That may be must be, love, on Thursday next.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: What must be shall be.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That's a certain text.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Come you to make confession to this father?

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To answer that, I should confess to you.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Do not deny to him that you love me.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: I will confess to you that I love him.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: So will ye, I am sure, that you love me.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If I do so, it will be of more price,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: The tears have got small victory by that;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: For it was bad enough before their spite.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: That is no slander, sir, which is a truth;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And what I spake, I spake it to my face.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: It may be so, for it is not mine own.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Are you at leisure, holy father, now;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or shall I come to you at evening mass?

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: My leisure serves me, pensive daughter, now.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: My lord, we must entreat the time alone.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: God shield I should disturb devotion!

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Juliet, on Thursday early will I rouse ye:

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.

speaker: PARIS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O shut the door! and when thou hast done so,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Come weep with me; past hope, past cure, past help!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Ah, Juliet, I already know thy grief;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: It strains me past the compass of my wits:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: I hear thou must, and nothing may prorogue it,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: On Thursday next be married to this county.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Tell me not, friar, that thou hear'st of this,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Unless thou tell me how I may prevent it:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If, in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Do thou but call my resolution wise,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And with this knife I'll help it presently.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And ere this hand, by thee to Romeo seal'd,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall be the label to another deed,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or my true heart with treacherous revolt

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Turn to another, this shall slay them both:

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Therefore, out of thy long-experienced time,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Give me some present counsel, or, behold,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: 'Twixt my extremes and me this bloody knife

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Which the commission of thy years and art

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Could to no issue of true honour bring.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Be not so long to speak; I long to die,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: If what thou speak'st speak not of remedy.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold, daughter: I do spy a kind of hope,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Which craves as desperate an execution.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: As that is desperate which we would prevent.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: If, rather than to marry County Paris,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Then is it likely thou wilt undertake

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A thing like death to chide away this shame,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: That copest with death himself to scape from it:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And, if thou darest, I'll give thee remedy.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O, bid me leap, rather than marry Paris,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: From off the battlements of yonder tower;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: O'er-cover'd quite with dead men's rattling bones,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: With reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Or bid me go into a new-made grave

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And hide me with a dead man in his shroud;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Things that, to hear them told, have made me tremble;

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: And I will do it without fear or doubt,

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold, then; go home, be merry, give consent

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To-morrow night look that thou lie alone;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Take thou this vial, being then in bed,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And this distilled liquor drink thou off;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: When presently through all thy veins shall run

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall keep his native progress, but surcease:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: No warmth, no breath, shall testify thou livest;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Like death, when he shuts up the day of life;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Each part, deprived of supple government,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And then awake as from a pleasant sleep.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Then, as the manner of our country is,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In the mean time, against thou shalt awake,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall Romeo by my letters know our drift,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And hither shall he come: and he and I

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Will watch thy waking, and that very night

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: And this shall free thee from this present shame;

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear,

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Abate thy valour in the acting it.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: Hold; get you gone, be strong and prosperous

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: In this resolve: I'll send a friar with speed

speaker: FRIAR LAURENCE
text_entry: To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Love give me strength! and strength shall help afford.

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Farewell, dear father!

speaker: JULIET
text_entry: Exeunt
